headline.main: Taliban's Brand of Zeal May Survive Their Rule

lead_paragraph: There are worse places to be than in an Afghan jail, though none immediately spring to mind. More than 150 young Pakistanis are prisoners in an old granary resembling a medieval dungeon in this village about 30 miles northwest of Jalalabad, in eastern Afghanistan. They volunteered to fight with the Taliban, walk over the mountains and into the gun sites of the anti-Taliban militias who now rule this region. But jail has not doused their fires.
abstract: More than 150 young Pakistanis are prisoners in old granary resembling medieval dungeon in eastern Afghan village, having volunteered to fight with Taliban, walked across mountains and into gun sites of anti-Taliban militias; fundamentalist fervor that gave Al Qaeda and Taliban life has yet not lost spark, and US bombing may be fueling sympathy even as Taliban rule is shattered (M)
